title: A second referendum is the first choice for more and more MPs
text:

Tom Watson could be forgiven for having a wry smile on his face.



Before the Labour conference he was denounced and then nearly lost his job for saying the party’s policy should be for a referendum on Brexit before a general election.



John McDonnell has since hinted he supports this position as does his ally Rebecca Long-Bailey who, ironically, was one of the NEC members who voted to abolish Watson’s position as revenge for his breaking ranks.



It now almost the official Labour line for everyone apart from Jeremy Corbyn.



Those who fear it will only deepen the Brexit divisions are starting to rethink their opposition on the grounds that an election in which Boris Johnson pitches people versus parliament will be just as divisive.



(Image: PA)



There is also an element of self survival here.



Labour believes it has a better chance of winning an election if Brexit has been dealt with and they can focus on their core message of ending austerity and creating a fairer country.



At last night's meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party MPs were not impressed when the party chair Ian Lavery insisted the party was ready for an election.



Those who want to hold their seats can suddenly see the advantage of a second referendum.



As Rachel Sylvester notes in the Times this morning , the same may even apply to some Tory MPs who are worried about the threat of the Brexit Party.



Others simply see it as the best way of halting Brexit.



The numbers are not yet there in the Commons but they could be if Corbyn drops his objections and demands a second poll as the condition for backing Johnson’s deal.

Much depends on the power struggle taking place in the Labour Party.



McDonnell is increasingly in control of Labour’s direction and is hungry for power.



Unlike some of the people around Corbyn he is prepared to be more pragmatic about what Labour needs to do to make itself electable.

(Image: REUTERS)





It also depends on what happens in Brussels this week.



In a sign that progress is being made Boris Johnson has put back the weekly Cabinet meeting from today until tomorrow.



This is to allow the British negotiators more time before giving the Cabinet a detailed update.



Though the Telegraph has suggested it is also to prevent an errant Cabinet leak from derailing the delicate discussions.



The EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier, who is updating EU ambassadors this morning, said this morning that reaching a deal this week “will be difficult” but is “still possible.”



Finnish Prime Minister Antti Rinne, whose country holds the rotating EU presidency, has warned more time will be needed to nail down an agreement before Thursday’s EU summit.



An extension is looking more and more likely.



If a deal is in sight would Johnson really reject it for the sake of a few more days of talks?

description: More and more MPs are coming round to the idea that a second referendum is better than a snap election
